typefaces.name: GT Canon
typefaces.description: Pragmatic but not static: movement and liveliness embedded in the letterforms. A contemporary serif for digital times. Sibling to GT Standard, aiming for modern functionality rather than stylistic reinvention.
typefaces.character: Modern functional serif with embedded liveliness

typefaces.name: GT Era
typefaces.description: Reimagines the warmth and idiosyncrasies of early grotesk typefaces. Inspired by Bauhaus and De Stijl. Shuns neutrality and embraces friction, championing recognition over uniformity and flavor over conformity.
typefaces.character: Warm, idiosyncratic early grotesk revival. Anti-neutral.

typefaces.name: GT Standard
typefaces.description: A contemporary response to the modernist pursuit of standardization. Rooted in Swiss Style principles, expanded for today's visual landscape. Systematic yet expressive, built for clarity, adaptability, and precision across every scale and medium.
typefaces.character: Swiss modernist workhorse sans-serif. Clean, systematic, precise.

typefaces.name: GT Flaire
typefaces.description: Captures the pronounced curves created by calligraphic pens under pressure, translated into digital format. Bridges business and pleasure, breaking free from corporate rigidity by combining seriousness with playfulness.
typefaces.character: Calligraphic serif bridging corporate and playful worlds

typefaces.name: GT Pantheon
typefaces.description: An interpretation of historic shapes in a contemporary manner. Expressive and dynamic character in every stroke. Three optically-adjusted faces (Display, Text, Micro) moving between elegance, sharpness, warmth and robustness.
typefaces.character: Historic serif reinterpreted. Grand, expressive, multi-optical.

typefaces.name: GT America
typefaces.description: The missing bridge between 19th century American Gothics and 20th century European Neo-Grotesk typefaces. Uses the best design features from both traditions in the widths and weights where they function optimally.
typefaces.character: American Gothic meets European Neo-Grotesk. Versatile workhorse.

typefaces.name: GT America Intl
typefaces.description: International collection variant of GT America with extended language support.
typefaces.character: GT America with broader international language coverage

typefaces.name: GT Pressura
typefaces.description: Inspired by metal type printing history and engineered letters stamped onto shipping boxes. Uses the visual gesture of ink spreading under pressure as a stylistic device, offering an alternative to spindly digital typefaces.
typefaces.character: Industrial, ink-spread aesthetic. Heavy, tactile, bold.

typefaces.name: GT Planar
typefaces.description: Tests the limits of a 90-degree range, combining Retalic, Upright, and Italic styles into one continuous design space. Transitions seamlessly from -45° Retalic to +45° Italic while retaining integrity.
typefaces.character: Experimental variable-angle sans-serif. Full-spectrum italic.

typefaces.name: GT Ultra
typefaces.description: Dances between the worlds of sans and serifs, fusing calligraphy and construction. Combines centuries-old serif context with modern sans dynamism, challenging its own definition and questioning typographic expectation.
typefaces.character: Genre-defying serif-sans hybrid. Calligraphic yet constructed.

typefaces.name: GT Maru
typefaces.description: An ode to rounded English characters found on signage across Japan. Explores roundness (maru) in the Latin alphabet. Combines the warmth and flow of sign painting with the mechanical quality of engraved letters.
typefaces.character: Japanese-inspired rounded sans. Warm, mechanical, sign-painted.

typefaces.name: GT Flexa
typefaces.description: Embraces the idea of a fluid design space instead of static styles. A dynamic tool enabling joyful typesetting that allows for fully responsive designs. An impressively extensive typographic system with distinctive personality.
typefaces.character: Fluid variable sans-serif. Joyful, extensive, responsive.

typefaces.name: GT Alpina
typefaces.description: Proudly calls itself a workhorse serif, but delights in playing with the very meaning of that concept. Reaches into the grab bag of typographic history to resurrect shapes some may falsely see as too expressive, melding distinct shapes with pragmatic execution.
typefaces.character: Expressive workhorse serif. Playful with typographic history.

typefaces.name: GT Zirkon
typefaces.description: An extravagant sans serif workhorse. Blends rational tool and ornamentation by applying techniques used to optimize type for small sizes in a refined way.
typefaces.character: Extravagant yet functional sans. Ornamental rationalism.

typefaces.name: GT Super
typefaces.description: The result of extensive investigation into display serif typefaces from the 1970s and 80s. Focuses on the expressive and idiosyncratic nature of calligraphic motions, compelled into stable typographic shapes.
typefaces.character: 70s/80s display serif revival. Calligraphic, expressive, retro.

typefaces.name: GT Walsheim
typefaces.description: Inspired by the lettering of Swiss poster designer legend Otto Baumberger from the 1930s. A friendly but precise typeface. Supports all Cyrillic languages.
typefaces.character: Friendly geometric sans inspired by 1930s Swiss poster lettering.

typefaces.name: GT Eesti
typefaces.description: A free-spirited interpretation of the Soviet geometric sans serif 'Zhurnalnaya Roublennaya'. Developed from books from Soviet-occupied Estonia, expanded into Display and Text subfamilies for Latin & Cyrillic.
typefaces.character: Soviet geometric revival. Free-spirited, historical, geometric.

typefaces.name: GT Cinetype
typefaces.description: Based on a design engineered for a cinema subtitling machine. A laser erases the color layer of film to create small, brilliantly white letters. The laser can only move in straight lines, so the typeface contains no curves.
typefaces.character: Cinema-subtitle origin. All straight lines, no curves. Technical, minimal.

typefaces.name: GT Haptik
typefaces.description: A monolinear geometric grotesque typeface. Uppercase letters and numbers optimized to be read blindfolded by touch. Seven weights with Oblique and Rotalic styles, alternate characters, proportional and tabular figures.
typefaces.character: Touch-optimized geometric sans. Tactile, accessible, clear.

typefaces.name: GT Sectra
typefaces.description: A contemporary serif combining the calligraphy of the broad nib pen with the sharpness of the scalpel knife. Originally designed for the long-form journalism magazine 'Reportagen'. Three subfamilies: GT Sectra, GT Sectra Fine, and GT Sectra Display.
typefaces.character: Sharp editorial serif. Pen calligraphy meets surgical precision.
